content: Just about every method for evaluating the election based on state polls seems to hint at a very slight lead in the popular vote, as well as an Electoral College victory, for President Obama.

Three of eight national tracking polls have announced temporary suspensions, and further polling delays and cancellations are likely over the next few days, especially in the Northeast. But Monday did offer some polls in the battleground states.
Pennsylvania is the only state that has been unfailingly Democratic-leaning relative to the national popular vote in every presidential election since 1950.

Hurricane Sandy is just too large a storm to make reliable guesses about where the vote might be depressed. And academic studies on the effects of natural disasters upon elections produce somewhat ambiguous results.
The presidential polling in most swing states now looks very similar to the way it did for much of the late spring and summer.
There were two polls out in Minnesota on Saturday: one gave President Obama an eight-point lead, but another had Mr. Obama with a smaller lead of just three points.

There are no precedents in the FiveThirtyEight database for a candidate losing with a two- or three-point lead in a state - President Obama's lead in Ohio - when the polling volume was as rich as it is there.
Thursday's polls served to clarify that Barack Obama maintains a narrow lead in states that would get him to 270 electoral votes.
Mitt Romney, who was born and raised in Michigan, does not appear to be contesting the state, and the FiveThirtyEight forecast gives President Obama a 97 percent chance of winning there.

Mitt Romney clearly gained ground in the polls in the week or two after the Denver debate. However, the FiveThirtyEight forecast finds a slightly favorable trend for President Obama over the past 10 days.
